title: Why Obama might choose to lose on guns
content:
The stance is part of a second-term Obama strategy of calculated confrontation . Why Obama may choose to lose on guns
President Barack Obama — hardheaded architect of many grand but flawed compromises in his first term — has always preferred winning ugly to losing nobly .
Over the years , Democrats have jokingly referred to what they call the “ Obama rule , ” enshrining the president ’ s practice of not forcing legislative action on anything , no matter how noble , that can ’ t pass both houses .
But the massacre in Newtown , Conn. , last month — and Obama ’ s pledge Wednesday to force Congress to act on an assault weapons ban , limits on high-capacity gun magazines and enhanced gun-tracking measures — is forcing the innately cautious Obama to break that rule . For one of the few instances in his presidency , he now appears willing to burn political capital by pressuring Senate Democrats to vote for a measure that is likely to die in the House , a symbolic victory that sets the stage , he hopes , for more meaningful ones .
Along with his tough stances on the debt ceiling , it ’ s part of a second-term strategy of calculated confrontation : Republicans won ’ t negotiate with him , so he plans to marshal popular opinion to force them into action .
“ I intend to use whatever weight this office holds to make [ the proposals ] a reality , ” Obama said at the White House on Wednesday . “ Congress too must act and must act soon . I ’ m calling on Congress to pass some very specific proposals right away . … They need to bring these proposals up for a vote . ”
“ This time must be different , ” he said on Wednesday , flanked by Vice President Joe Biden , who oversaw the drafting of the gun package . “ I will put everything I ’ ve got into this . … I tell you the only way we can change is if the American people demand it . ”
In reality , Obama has no alternative but to push ahead , given the magnitude of the Newtown tragedy and his emotional reaction to it . He has framed the gun issue as a moral imperative — and can ’ t abide inaction , not after the tearful pledge he made to victims ’ families .
Still , if Obama follows through — and many Democrats privately question whether he will — it would represent a significant shift in his own perception of the presidency .

But the massacre in Newtown, Conn., last month — and Obama’s pledge Wednesday to force Congress to act on an assault weapons ban, limits on high-capacity gun magazines and enhanced gun-tracking measures — is forcing the innately cautious Obama to break that rule. For one of the few instances in his presidency, he now appears willing to burn political capital by pressuring Senate Democrats to vote for a measure that is likely to die in the House, a symbolic victory that sets the stage, he hopes, for more meaningful ones.

Along with his tough stances on the debt ceiling, it’s part of a second-term strategy of calculated confrontation: Republicans won’t negotiate with him, so he plans to marshal popular opinion to force them into action.

“I intend to use whatever weight this office holds to make [the proposals] a reality,” Obama said at the White House on Wednesday. “Congress too must act and must act soon. I’m calling on Congress to pass some very specific proposals right away. … They need to bring these proposals up for a vote.”

“This time must be different,” he said on Wednesday, flanked by Vice President Joe Biden, who oversaw the drafting of the gun package. “I will put everything I’ve got into this. … I tell you the only way we can change is if the American people demand it.”

( PHOTOS: Obama visits Sandy Hook memorial service)

In reality, Obama has no alternative but to push ahead, given the magnitude of the Newtown tragedy and his emotional reaction to it. He has framed the gun issue as a moral imperative — and can’t abide inaction, not after the tearful pledge he made to victims’ families.

Still, if Obama follows through — and many Democrats privately question whether he will — it would represent a significant shift in his own perception of the presidency.
